pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:0.5: The training rule on malicious talebearing
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in the Jeta Grove, Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.2: At that time the monks from the group of six were engaged in malicious talebearing between monks who were arguing.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.3: After hearing something on one side they reported it to the other side, and vice versa, in order to create division between them.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.4: In this way new quarrels were created and existing quarrels became worse.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.7: “How can the monks from the group of six engage in malicious talebearing between monks who are arguing?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.8: How can they report to one side what they have heard on the other side, and vice versa, in order to create division,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.9: and in this way create new quarrels and make existing quarrels worse?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.10: After criticizing those monks in many ways, they told the Master. …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.11: “Is it true, monks, that you do this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.15: “… Foolish men, how can you engage in malicious talebearing between monks who are arguing?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.16: How can you report to one side what you have heard on the other side, and vice versa, in order to create division,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.17: and in this way create new quarrels and make existing quarrels worse?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.18: This will not give rise to confidence in those without it
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.19: or increase the confidence of those who have it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.20: And, monks, this training rule should be recited thus:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:1.21: ‘If a monk engages in malicious talebearing between monks, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.1.2: there is malicious talebearing in two ways:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.1.3: for one wanting to endear himself or for one aiming at division.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.1.4: One engages in malicious talebearing in ten ways:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.1.5: about caste, about name, about family, about work, about craft, about illnesses, about physical traits, about defilements, about offenses, and by insulting.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.1.7: there are two kinds of castes:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.1.10: outcasts, bamboo workers, hunters, chariot-makers, waste-removers—
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.1.15: To be expanded as in [Pācittiya 2, paragraphs 9–16](pli-tv-bu-vb-pc2#9).
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.1.17: there are two kinds of insults:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.1.20: “you’re a camel/you’re a ram/you’re an ox/you’re a donkey/you’re an animal/you’re bound for hell/you’re not going to a good destination/you can only expect a bad destination,” or adding the disparaging endings _ya_ or _bha_ to someone’s name, or calling someone words for the male and female genitals—
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc3:2.1.23: “you’re wise/you’re competent/you’re intelligent/you’re learned/you’re an expounder of the Teaching/you’re not going to a bad destination/you can only expect a good destination”—
